text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> thanks, will apply :)

<@UE3KC0VK6>: It might be more powerful, but I don't think in metaprogramming: as I understand, RxJS *runs* JS to create the expression tree. So basically you have a turing-complete preprocessor. I don't have enough primitives for eval-time turing completeness, but that should just be a matter of time as far as I can tell. The differences to Obervable as far as I can tell are two:

1.) My language has explicitly defined semantics and UX for updating the graph at runtime. This is the main contribution I think, I'm not expecting to come up with a better general purpose FRP language here.
2.) The metaprogramming and flowbased logic have the same syntax and share some semantics. The metaprogramming only runs at eval-time, but at eval-time a single tick of flow-logic is also executed incrementally as the tree is built. Due to the dependency tracking, it is also known whether values are dependent on the root event or not. Based on this, the metaprogramming operations can access computation results, and determine whether values are subject to future changes or not. So (+ 3 3) is an eval-time constant, while (+ 3 (time/count 1)) is not (time/count has an implicit  dependency on the root event). It's essentially constant folding.

The metaprogramming only runs at eval-time, but at eval-time a single tick of flow-logic is also executed incrementally as the tree is built. Due to the dependency tracking, it is also known whether values are dependent on the root event or not. text: Updating the graph (as in rewiring it, not just updating values?) is super cool!

elements.text: Updating the graph (as in rewiring it, not just updating values?) is super cool!

text: <@UE3KC0VK6> yup, both rewiring and updating constants are supported with no compromises :) I don't know much about ObservableHQ, so I can't really compare to that currently.

elements.text: yup, both rewiring and updating constants are supported with no compromises :) I don't know much about ObservableHQ, so I can't really compare to that currently.

text: What does no compromises mean, no recalculation besides downstream of the new dependency link? Also do expressions have access to their previous values?

elements.text: What does no compromises mean, no recalculation besides downstream of the new dependency link? Also do expressions have access to their previous values?

text:
previous to what? expressions keep their identity + local state when re-evaluating the code, even when their inputs change or they are moved to another expressions input etc.
By no compromises I mean that it doesn't rely on a best-effort text diffing algorithm or something like that, any kind of restructuring is fully supported.

elements.text:
previous to what? expressions keep their identity + local state when re-evaluating the code, even when their inputs change or they are moved to another expressions input etc.
By no compromises I mean that it doesn't rely on a best-effort text diffing algorithm or something like that, any kind of restructuring is fully supported.

text: identity (+ therefore local state) is only lost when an expression crosses some domain boundaries where this is undefined, like moving an expression out of or into a loop or a function.

elements.text: identity (+ therefore local state) is only lost when an expression crosses some domain boundaries where this is undefined, like moving an expression out of or into a loop or a function.

text: Ok, I'm still wrapping my head around the local state and identity

elements.text: Ok, I'm still wrapping my head around the local state and identity

text: <@UE3KC0VK6> <https://youtu.be/ZXqgFb1U7q0?t=276> , pay attention to the transitions when changes are made: the lfo operator is not recreated when its parameters change, it keeps running from its last position. It is not recreated because it has a continous identity across reevaluations, and therefore it can hold on to its local state (the phase of the oscillation) as well.

text: Next I'm curious about the interface I need to implement to write my own things like lfo in the video - do they need to be able to be updated?

text: <@UE3KC0VK6> for most operators, the update procedure is the same as the init procedure. Currently there is three hooks - the constructor, "setup" and "tick". setup is called every time there are new parameters (including right after the constructor).

elements.text: for most operators, the update procedure is the same as the init procedure. Currently there is three hooks - the constructor, "setup" and "tick". setup is called every time there are new parameters (including right after the constructor).

text: tick is not really time dependent, it gets triggered whenever any of the input streams are 'dirty'. This is what I'm fiddling with currently; there is a kind of dichotomy between 'event streams' and 'value streams' and I'm figuring out where that separation should be made (is it the value type? is it a style of reacting to changes? is it a style of output stream?)

elements.text: tick is not really time dependent, it gets triggered whenever any of the input streams are 'dirty'. This is what I'm fiddling with currently; there is a kind of dichotomy between 'event streams' and 'value streams' and I'm figuring out where that separation should be made (is it the value type? is it a style of reacting to changes? is it a style of output stream?)

text: event streams are 'dirty' even if the value is the same as the previous one (e.g. playing the note C then some time later the note C again - two events). Between events the stream is 'empty'. On the other hand value streams are always at a value, and may even want to be interpolated. They don't need to be marked dirty when the new value is the old, and reassigning an input from one value stream to another shouldn't be considered a change when the values are the same either.

elements.text: event streams are 'dirty' even if the value is the same as the previous one (e.g. playing the note C then some time later the note C again - two events). Between events the stream is 'empty'. On the other hand value streams are always at a value, and may even want to be interpolated. They don't need to be marked dirty when the new value is the old, and reassigning an input from one value stream to another shouldn't be considered a change when the values are the same either.

text: <https://tidalcycles.org/index.php/What_is_a_pattern%3F> confirmed my understanding of these two being different (here considered 'digital' and 'analog'  streams), and also let me notice that I do need ('digital') event-streams to be able to carry multiple events in a single frame

text: Reading a bit on Barbour's RDP, events are completely eliminated in his design. I'll have to think on whether that is an option or not, it seems like he acknowledges that this is not a universal solution.

elements.text: Reading a bit on Barbour's RDP, events are completely eliminated in his design. I'll have to think on whether that is an option or not, it seems like he acknowledges that this is not a universal solution.

text: I don't understand him very well, and it's been several years since I read about RDP. It seemed quite rigorous and principled.

elements.text: I don't understand him very well, and it's been several years since I read about RDP. It seemed quite rigorous and principled.

text: yes, same here on understanding it. i think the design is really about the distributed and eventual consistency goals, which is very unlike what i (think i) need for this application (livecoding)

elements.text: yes, same here on understanding it. i think the design is really about the distributed and eventual consistency goals, which is very unlike what i (think i) need for this application (livecoding)

text: I'm willing to make compromises on many principles that help keep complicated big codebases and distributed systems maintainable if it helps have an environment that is effective for small audio-visual pieces and easy to manipulate live. It's really meant to be a duct-tape language for realtime processing

It's really meant to be a duct-tape language for realtime processing

text: Good design space, interested to see what you do. Do you plan to have tick capped at 60 fps or something like that, or do you get multiple tick calls for multiple events the same frame?

elements.text: Good design space, interested to see what you do. Do you plan to have tick capped at 60 fps or something like that, or do you get multiple tick calls for multiple events the same frame?

text: right now the root event clocks about every millisecond, then everything time-clocked gets a delta event from a clock, which slows that down to 60fps

elements.text: right now the root event clocks about every millisecond, then everything time-clocked gets a delta event from a clock, which slows that down to 60fps
